From chatGPT "Senator Cynthia Lummis's proposed "Boosting Innovation, Technology, and Competitiveness through Optimized Investment Nationwide (BITCOIN) Act" outlines the establishment of a strategic Bitcoin reserve for the United States. The bill specifies that the U.S. Department of the Treasury would be responsible for managing this reserve through a decentralized network of secure Bitcoin vaults. These vaults are mandated to adhere to stringent physical and cybersecurity protocols to ensure the highest level of security for the nation's Bitcoin holdings. 
LUMMIS.SENATE.GOV

While the bill emphasizes the importance of robust security measures, it does not detail the specific custody mechanisms, such as the use of multi-signature (multi-sig) wallets or the involvement of third-party custodians like Coinbase. The focus is on self-custody by the Treasury, utilizing secure vaults under its direct operation."

So it looks like US Gov self custody, probably something like a big multi sig with several redundant physical keys, total guess but say 11/15 multi sig 9 people and 6 geographically unique locations in bomb proof bunkers.  Keyholders could be designated people like fed reserve chair, VP or custodians like Coinbase, Cantor fitzgerald or companies like Casa.  Alternatively they could custody at 1 or more custodians like Coinbase etc  Or they could hold ETFs.  The Sovereign wealth fund could also be a backdoor way to hold BTC too, ETFs, MSTR, Miners etc

It needs to be done right, USA level they have the technical know how to do self custody properly, UK/Australia Gov level I wouldn't trust them, Custodian or ETFs for them.  I think nation state adoption is a foregone conclusion I just hope my Gov isn't the one that fucks it up and gets all the others to do it properly.

I've also heard rumours the US Marshalls holding the 200k Silk road BTC are a mess, spreadsheets of the private keys and awful sounding stuff, they may even have lost it already.

¬´Morning pages¬ª ‚Äì a writing habit that sticks ‚úçÔ∏è 

I‚Äôve heard many of us want to share more content whether it‚Äôs on X, a newsletter, a podcast, or etc. But staying consistent is hard. 
Personally, I want to grow my X, kick off interview series, start sharing my thoughts within the Network School and beyond. But without a system, it‚Äôs easy to push writing aside. 

 I thought it would be helpful to shape a new habit and support each other in a group. 
Here is the idea of writing routine ¬´Morning pages¬ª: a space to write together, a couple of times per week. Just 30-40 minutes of focused writing ‚Äì whether it's a tweet, a Substack post, or even a movie scenario. And ideally a finished post by the end.

Writing alone is hard. Writing with others is way easier.

some of you asked me about the format: it will be a 45-60 min lecture to get on the same page about the current and upcoming capabilities and then 30 min discussion how to apply AI agents to help NS scale

Some immediate ideas of applying AI Agents to help NS Team scale:
1) Support bot that helps to answer questions around logistics, lectures, etc.
2) Applicant qualification bot that downloads applicant's info from LI, X, Farcaster, etc. and performs qualification using some pre-defined criteria. Think of this as a pre-screening
3) Application voice bot - bot will call you back and you can answer the questions, provide more context for the qualification

I‚Äôm all for crypto‚ÄîI‚Äôve been in the trenches and seen it all. But there‚Äôs Bitcoin, and then there‚Äôs crypto. This move hands centralized shitcoiners the power to print U.S. government fiat, completely missing the point of Bitcoin. Bitcoin exists to defund and shift power away from the Federal Reserve, not to create a new class of digital central bankers.

XRP has always been a joke‚Äîdumping coins on holders‚Äînow they get to print fiat, diluting both U.S. government reserves and taxpayers‚Äô holdings. Why hand this power to shitcoiners? The Bybit hack proves ETH is an overcomplicated, insecure mess.

Bitcoin doesn‚Äôt need the U.S. government‚Äîthe U.S. government needs BTC as a store of value. Mixing BTC‚Äôs role with crypto nonsense only adds unnecessary risk. There is no second best. When the shitcoiners get greedy or hacked, this whole experiment will collapse, jeopardizing BTC adoption.

And when North Korea inevitably hacks the U.S. government's ETH multi-sig, what‚Äôs stopping Elizabeth Warren from liquidating everything and setting Bitcoin adoption back years?

Yes, agreed, many of us -- and our children -- have been at some point a third culture kid or close to it. 

It's arguably a paradox, the situation our world is in: On one hand, much of our world is moving forward in ways that maximize diffusion of ideas, experiences, and cultures -- from the Internet to population centers like London/NYC/Dubai/Hong Kong/Singapore and even popup villages in Bali/Chiang Mai. On the other hand, "Insert XYZ-Nation-State First" politics and ideas are becoming more indoctrinated/institutionalized, decoupling and de-globalization is becoming the norm, paving way for a more late 1800's Wild Wild West with tariff wars and other rising nationalism. 

I look forward to learning from you and co-exploring hopefully ways in which our kids could thrive in this world through better education and openness.

I absolutely understand! This is such an exciting topic for me. In 1984, sociologist Dr. Ted Ward called Third Culture Kids "the prototype citizens of the future," and I strongly agree with him.
Today, a childhood spent between multiple cultures is no longer rare, and there are several reasons behind this. Sometimes, parents choose to move abroad for fun or work, while other times, people are forced to relocate due to political circumstances, leaving them with no other options.
TCKs form a highly diverse group, yet they share a common identity as individuals who have developed connections with different countries, cultures, and mindsets during their formative years.
I am sure NS will be full of TCKs. üôÇ

I empathize. It's a struggle and balance that arguably many third culture families/kids and immigrant families/kids face. There is a desire to keep up with the original culture/roots. There is also the care to make sure that patriotism does not slide into nationalism (it's sometimes a slippery slope). Then there's sometimes the conflict or struggle when a host country's ethos/national ideas -- ones that may be indoctrinated early in schools -- go against the home country's ethos/national ideas.

I grew up partially in Miami, with many school mates who had families from places such as Cuba and Venezuela. Sometimes I would wonder how my Cuban/Venezuelan school mates balanced between their home country's roots and their host country's politics/ideas, which continues to sanction/blockade/denigrade their motherland. (Then again, Castro was perceived negatively, so maybe that helped tip the scale.) 

My wife's grandmother was at one time Malaysian Chinese from Penang. The Malaysian Chinese for decades struggled to balance this: cast away/abandoned by the 1950s-1960s PRC Chinese state as de-facto foreigners, but also disregarded by 1950s-1960s Malaysian state sometimes as 2nd class people (Singapore was born partially because of this!). For a while during mid-20th century, there was a struggle to keep Chinese language schools alive in Malaysia, while kids grew up under a national education policy that was intended to reduce this culture. (It was more extreme in Suharto's Indonesia, where at one time the national indoctrination was to force kids in the Chinese diaspora to take up new names and be forbidden from cultural expression in public places.)

‚ù§Ô∏è Actually I really love my home country, and I want my kids to feel like they have strong roots and connections there. So for example letting them to forget their mother tongue is not an option in our family. But at the same time I do not like egocentric nationalism, feeling superior than other people only because I was born somewhere, I hate that. I believe in strong roots and powerful wings at the same time.  üôÇ

* A visitor or tourist should have the option to opt-in voluntarily. It should be on a voluntary basis, like with an airline loyalty rewards program. (Though one could argue whether voluntary opt-in is realistic if a revenue-hungry nation state were to really implement a similiar program.)
* The current nation-state border system is bureaucracy at best, and at worst a form of "affirmative action" identity politic: for example, if you have a G7 nation-state passport then you get 90 days, else you only get 30 days or if you are from Niger etc then you need to apply for a visa. This alternative could introduce more "meritocracy".
Probably the standard list of pros/cons of social credit systems applies to this idea

**Hypothetical Case Example:**
Suppose Malaysia were to roll out a ‚ÄúMyMalaysia‚Äù program for tourists and visitors such as NS members. 
* At the airport or immigration point, tourists/visitors can spend 40 Ringget (about 10 USD) to purchase a MyMalaysia card and link their passport ID to the card. 
* Tourists/visitors could swipe the MyMalaysia card when making purchases and spending at participating venues, such as national parks, Malaysian tourist attractions, local hotels, Malaysian Airlines, and other participating local restaurants/shops etc. 
* Different types purchases could translate into different number of points (just like with credit card reward programs); for example, national park ticket purchases could equate with higher point translation.
* If the tourist/visitor accumulates an annual point total higher than certain thresholds, then he/she could be awarded via a tier system that could begin with visa free status/incrementally higher # days per stay status, and other potential perks that cost little for the nation state but could encourage more tourist revenue collection.
* Other perks in the rewards program could include lower thresholds or shorter wait times for digital nomad visas or permanent residence visas.
* Any criminal activity or disapproved activity in violation of laws would result in automatic cancellation of MyMalaysia card and forfeiture of points/benefits.

An onchain solution to this could make data more secure and less corruptable, but in theory a v1 does not necessarily need to be onchain.

Building on the topic of nation-state immigration officers pounding us on "how long are you staying?" or "where do you go next‚Äù‚Ä¶one could argue that it‚Äôs a terrible inefficiency. Tying visa status/‚Äú# days allowed to stay‚Äù uniformly based on a nation-state passport is arguably an inefficient concept. That‚Äôs bureaucracy, not meritocracy.

**Thesis: If airlines could offer frequent flyer programs, and credit cards could offer rewards programs, and certain countries are already offering Gold Visas for high net worth individuals, nation states should offer frequent visitors/tourists/digital nomads ‚Äúa rewards point system‚Äù based on $ spent inside their borders.
**
The nation state rewards tourists/frequent travelers/digital nomads with points based on $ spent; high point totals could translate into visa-free status/higher # days stay status and other perks. Possible benefits (not an exhaustive list):
* Higher GDP boost from tourism
* ‚ÄúMeritocracy‚Äù to encourage desirable visitors to come back
* More measurable data on visitor spending patterns

our species is horribly tribal and often just fucking shitty (eg https://www.foxnews.com/world/70-christians-beheaded-african-country-isis-aligned-militants-groups-say-world-mostly-silent). imo, blockchain+AI is a way to lessen tribalism by making it possible to take some of the power out of the hands of humans, at least until our hardware (brain wiring) catch up with our software (reasoning and thought) and societal culture. also, i realize that this idea implies that someone or some group must 'correctly' understand the problem and accurately see the world to be able to correctly determine which things should be determined for everyone...this is a very tough problem and i don't really have a proposition on how to answer it.

i agree re 'don't be evil'. that was just an example. but, if, for example, you put voting on the blockchain and said only citizens of the country, w/ valid ID, could vote in that country's election, then (assuming a majority voted for such a thing to happen), it would be very, very difficult to then change such a thing later on (i know there are plenty of people that don't agree with this or national borders, for that matter). another example i can think of is to make child abuse illegal, in all forms...obvs, you need to define such a thing as well as you can, but only insane people and cultures don't protect children (who can't protect themselves.

i guess, my point is, there seem to be some overarching rules/laws/maxims/whatever that seem to be good for the entire species and, if they were enshrined on a 'national level' blockchain, then they would be even harder to change than the US constitution, which is notoriously difficult to change...for good reason. that said, i do recognize that it's possible for bad laws/rules to be put on the chain, which could cause massive trouble...but, like Uncle Ben said, w/ great power comes great responsibility ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Following up on the topic of camps and education for kids, there is a lot of good focus on the science, technology and problem solving. That's good. It's always good to see kids at an early age develop curiosity to scientific discovery, technology acceleration and problem solving.

The part that's been a pain point (open question) and arguably more controversial is around the social science and humanities aspects that eventually pop up. For us adults, many of our social and national ideas were shaped at an early age by the narratives that dominated our early education.
* Arguably, religious indoctrination could feature heavily in some form early on. I am not saying that's bad...as religion stories teach kids morals and other good things, but early indoctrination also shapes kids' minds in binary forms.
* Arguably, nationalist indoctrination could also feature heavily very early on. Nationalist stories could be packed and indoctrinated into the minds of 4-5 year olds. These stories and sentiments are hard to shake off, even when the kids grow up into rational adults.

It's not a coincidence that most nation states require that their schools have kids as young as 4-5 years old stand in front of a national flag every morning and sing a national anthem. It's early indoctrination at an early age that will stay with the kid throughout his/her lifetime.

And we see this eventually manifested in how many of our leaders and congressmen/women eventually treat the world as black/white binary.

Re: your question.  US and China are not necessarily on the opposite extremes of Individual Agency vs Cooperation. One could argue though, that the US tends to culturally fall more under Individual Agency hemisphere whereas China tends to culturally fall under Cooperation hemisphere. Two of the biggest superheroes / cultural icons illustrate this:

Ironman (USA): Tony Stark is the embodiment of self-made success, intellect, and individual willpower. Despite not having inherent superpower, he transforms himself through individual agency and technology. He constantly innovates, refines his technology, and refuses to let governments or institutions dictate his role as a hero. He believes in individual action and self-determination as key winning factors.

Sun Wukong (China): Wukong is the embodiment of enlightenment through order and collective potential. Wukong begins as an arrogant, rebellious figure who challenges Heaven itself, defeating celestial armies through sheer might and trickery. But instead of becoming a self-determined hero, his arc is about learning humility and cooperation‚Äîhe is ultimately tamed by Buddha and embarks on a journey to India where his power is placed in service of a greater collective purpose. His fulfillment comes from understanding his place in the grand order of things.

To build on the ongoing discussion: In some ways, one could argue that the US model and Chinese model are both converging into** tech capitalist nationalism**. The alternative is **tech capitalist globalism** that visionaries like Balaji have been leading via network state / network societies. Both models --- tech capitalist nationalism and tech capitalist globalism --- could co-exist for a long time. 

USA: "America First" political directive, tariff weaponization (at expense of Canada, Europe, etc), protectionist policies toward domestic manufacturing and prioritization of American tech/innovation at all costs
China: Rare minerals weaponization, identification of national technology champions in key technology sectors (autonomous vehicles, clean energy, AI, robotics, semiconductors, etc)

America under Trump and CCP/CPC under Xi are very similar in ideology and practice:
* Both stress strong nationalist culture and revival (Make America Great Again vs Rejuvenation of Chinese Nation)
* Both emphasize traditional family values 
* Both are anti-woke
* Both favor transactional pragmatic foreign policies
* Both weaponize trade
* Both put priority on national security and secure borders
* Both spur anti-corruption drives
* Both support key national technology innovation
* Both see value of transformative technology entrepreneur leaders (Trump with Elon, Sam, Zuck, Jensen, etc....Xi recently with Liang Wenfeng, Ren Zhengfei, etc)

Opponents of Trump may call Trump "fascist", opponents of CCP/CPC may call it "communist", but in essence both are really just tech nationalist, arguably two sides of the same coin. Not arguing that it is good or bad...it is what it is.

Once you define the frame of reference, then sure, there can be some consensus on what could work best in this context for travel (for example, on 3 dimensional space with Earth as frame of reference while applying Newtonian physics). 

And regarding consensus...

From a social science perspective, you could actually argue that in a given community, which sets a context or frame of reference, members could, through a consensus protocol, reach agreement on a particular "truth".  On a micro level, in a particular blockchain, the distributed consensus protocol keeps the network coherent by ensuring all participants agree on the same "truth" (the current state of the blockchain) through a shared process. But on a more macro level, you could have different blockchains with differing concensus protocols.

These two sides are not necessarily contradictory:
On macro level, pluralism: "Truth" could depend on varying context, frame of reference, and protocol. 
On micro level, consensus: Once frame of reference is defined, context is set, and consensus protocol agreed upon, a set of participants could reach a local "truth".

Good to hear from you Mili! To build on the discussion on shaping of narratives...

Arguably, one of the key reasons for Tiktok ban in the US is that the establishment is unable to shape narratives on TikTok. To borrow a Balaji term -- it doesn't have root control over TikTok.  

Arguably, the Great Firewall of the East was also erected in part to stabilize narratives. Though there is a technical difference: if a tech company complies with Chinese laws, it can operate inside the wall (whether those laws are perceived as stringent is a different discussion). Many Western tech giants made a conscious decision to stay outside the wall. In TikTok's situation, it has made efforts to comply with US laws (whether those efforts are perceived as sufficient is a different discussion), while the establishment made a conscious decision to ban/force sale regardless.

Whether it is firewall or ban/ejection/forced sale, the action creates a digital barrier to make it easier to shape/enforce mainstream narratives. But time and time again, we see that the network's organic, grassroots strength could prevail. What makes the recent situation interesting is the direction of flow...it's as if the East German establishment originally made the wall, but the West Germans are so fed up with "West German" propaganda that they break the wall and go to East Germany this time (and find that "East Germany" is actually in some ways wealthier). For a moment in time, there is a conjuring of that image where East Germans and West Germans celebrate a common humanity without artificial barriers or enforced narratives from either side's propaganda.

The issue of how narratives are shaped is arguably very relevant to NS and network society movement. We are already seeing a relatively negative mainstream narrative (for example, previous BBC article, etc) that is being slapped onto us. Reading that BBC article, it almost feels like a mainstream narrative was already pre-determined to be slapped on -- in that vein, it was arguably smart for the NS group to not engage with mainstream media too early and to not play their game with their rules. Digital barriers make it easier for those negative mainstream narratives to stick longer. But the organic, grassroots power of the network would prevail eventually.

Posted this in another TNS discussion thread, thought this recent development has potential ramifications for the network society movement, so re-posting in the discussion thread here. Balaji had previously during his lecture astutely made an insight about history being in reverse. Here is another recent example:

In the 1950's and 1960's, the East erected and guarded a wall in Berlin against supposed Western influence, while thousands of people from the East tried to flee and seek refuge in the West by breaking through that wall.

In the Internet era, a Great Firewall also exists, while it is the West that is now becoming increasingly concerned about alleged Eastern influence (e.g. recent TikTok ban), and hundreds of thousands of Internet users from the West (especially Americans) are now organically trying to flock to the Internet of the East through apps like Xiaohongshu / RedNote (which ironically is literally named after "The Little Red Book" of communist origin).

Times change. There is a breaking the "Berlin Wall" potential to this Xiaohongshu / RedNote development. Few people saw this coming. People are wondering how long this organic network-driven breaking of digital barriers erected by nation states could last. If it lasts, there could be major lessons and takeaways for the network society movement.
